bestBHT.bht: Paul was unjustly accused of being a pestilent fellow and a mover of sedition among all the Jews. He was further labeled a ringleader of the sect of the Nazarenes, a group despised by the Romans. These false charges were meant to discredit Paul and hinder the spread of Christianity. However, these accusations lacked substance and aimed to blemish Paul's character and the reputation of the early church.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: a pestilent fellow—a plague, or pest.
a mover of sedition among all the Jews—by exciting disturbances among them.
a ringleader of the sect of the Nazarenes—the second charge; and true enough.
Albert Barnes: Tertullus did not say that he was a pestilent fellow, but that he was the very pestilence itself.
This they pretended he did by preaching doctrines contrary to the laws and customs of Moses, and exciting the Jews to tumult and disorder.
The meaning is, that Paul had been so active, and so prominent in preaching the gospel, that he had been a leader, or the principal person in extending the sect of the Nazarenes.
Marvin Vincent: Pestilent fellow [λοιμον]. Lit., a plague or pest.
Ringleader [πρωτοστατην]. Originally, one who stands first on the right of a line; a file - leader.
Nazarenes. The only passage in scripture where this term is used to denote the Christians.
John Calvin: But if we like the former exposition better, he doth craftily lay to Paul’s charge that he was one of that sect which the Romans did hate.
Moreover, they slander Paul impudently, for no man did think that he was guilty of that crime.
Such is the careless security of hypocrites, that they think they may do whatsoever they will, so they color their doings with zeal.
Philip Schaff: The Greek word rendered ‘a pestilent fellow,’ literally signifies ‘a plague or pestilence.’ But it is used by Demosthenes, as here, to designate a designing, dangerous person.
This charge of teaching sedition was no new one...The jealous Roman governors were always ready to give ear to any information respecting alleged treason against the Majesty of the state.

They were eager to call ‘the Crucified Lord’ the Nazarene, the citizen of a nameless city; and they chose the dishonoured title as the heritage of those who called Him Master and Lord, styling them ‘Nazarenes.’
Archibald T. Robertson: Paul the pest. Think of the greatest preacher of the ages being branded a pest by a contemporary hired lawyer.
A ringleader of the sect of the Nazarenes. This charge is certainly true.
The disciple is not above his Master. There was a sneer in the term as applied to Jesus and here to his followers.
John Gill: For we have found this man a pestilent fellow...to call him the pest of the city, or of the country, or of the empire.
And a mover of sedition among all the Jews throughout the world...he stirred up all the Jews to it, and that in every part of the world, or empire.
And a ringleader of the sect of the Nazarenes...to make the apostle more odious.

bhtAttempts.bht: Paul was slandered by Tertullus, who labeled him as a pestilent fellow and a mover of sedition among all the Jews. This was not only a false accusation, but it also carried a sneering tone towards Jesus and His followers. Tertullus accused Paul of being a ringleader of the sect of the Nazarenes, using a term specifically chosen to dishonor and degrade those who believed in Jesus. It is clear that the intention was to brand Paul as a troublemaker and a nuisance, seeking to harm his reputation and cause harm to the cause of Christ. However, these accusations were baseless and far from the truth.

Paul was falsely accused by Tertullus of being a pestilent fellow and a mover of sedition among all the Jews. These derogatory labels were intended to demean and discredit him. Tertullus also accused Paul of being a ringleader of the sect of the Nazarenes, using a term that sought to degrade the followers of Jesus. However, these accusations were unfounded and aimed at tarnishing Paul's reputation and undermining the spread of the Gospel.

Paul was unjustly denounced as a pestilent fellow, someone akin to a plague or pest, and as a mover of sedition among all the Jews, someone who incites turmoil. He was further accused of being a ringleader of the sect of the Nazarenes, a term used to belittle and disparage followers of Jesus. These unfounded allegations were meant to defame Paul, undermine his credibility, and impede the advancement of the Gospel. However, these accusations held no merit and only sought to tarnish the truth.

These false accusations aimed to malign Paul's reputation and undermine his message. Tertullus, in particular, sought to discredit Paul by using derogatory terms associated with troublemakers and by associating him with a despised sect. However, these claims were baseless and designed to hinder the spread of the Gospel.
